title: John Newton Johnson to Walt Whitman, 20 May 1877
text: Meltonsville Alabama—Breaking the Sabbath, May 20 1877To Walt Whitman While most of what I have written to further amid a sort of tion of for spells of tedium lonesomeness exceptional—just now I begin freeness and soothing or happy out coming from a pure bodily feeling and sleeping today, for the remorse interruption of health.) Scenery— earth, bright sunshine, numerous a brisk, changeable breeze, a world every direction—no flowers,and I you could forgive me for this—but you what has been a frequent mine—"if all the things which are done, were left undone, and all the which are barely undone, were done, the world every way would present a very different appearance." P.S. Isn't this worth a postage stamp? I, myself, represent "falsehoods," and "the sale of slaves"—4 or 5 years before my father and mother were married, he was engaged to another woman in another State—going off to Virginia a few slaves, the woman when he towards home with his was that another man, and she cried —(the tale as it was told me after cook woman who was then a I am put this letter into ParagraphsA neighbor's child was drowned the other day, but restored—its parents temporarily absent from home, returned and found their 4 year old boy in the bottom of a shallow well, dead. I would remark upon the nation of distress and happiness felt. that child and all they sometime he again, and probably after suffering. We should be prepared before for invasions." Mr. Sanders in Madison County next this. I had heard a little about him before. During 20 years he has had what they call "sleeping spells" lasting from minutes to hours and days. It is hardly to be doubted that he has been seeing and accurately in an unusual way. Phil. (which I happened to buy long —Dreaming, Somnambulist, Insanity, Coincidences, his own absurd reasoning all there. I have studied, and studied, and studied—taking it easy tho'—thought I ought to go to see Sanders; till I saw the D— had left him. From May till Sept the man remained well. Take note that I have been fearing that you may be to some degree seduced by the professor people's growing kindness. (Walt! be a renegade—you must stand by "wicked and and —please stand by them let no blandishments *Are you not ambiguous in "Two Rivulets" latter part note "FreedI have never read Books on "Political Economy", but during the last year have studied more on the subject of Profit on Capital—concluded that perhaps no at all would be nearer right—at least to be very small indeed—the opportune for I have various with in mostly poor, who prepared to pay Interest—I can more pity borrowers and renters.—You old rascal! you have declined to say you would advise me about books to buy—I would'nt[wouldn't] have much—I shall not have much to spare to buy any books—(I will always have enough to buy all that ) I did want to ask if you thought I would pleased and some profited by Emerson's.As I only made half year, and price of cotton seems to have settled down permanently, I spent last year several times as much as I made—also during same time became pretty well convinced that a good deal of debts owing to me will never be paid. I dont feel so rich as I did 3 years ago, but if so resolute a man, so lastingly thoughtful a man, can't along well enough to satisfy such please to me who should? suppose that I shall find myself ingenious?
